member.name: T:Northwoods.Go.Xml.GoXmlBindingTransformer
member.summary: This class implements a with which you can easily declare a binding between XML attributes and properties, and which automatically makes a copy of a object when consuming an XML element for this transformer.

remarks.para: Use this kind of transformer when you have complete control over the XML schema that you want to read and write and can follow the conventions established by this class.

The following two transformers are similar to the SimpleXmlTransformBasicNode and SimpleXmlTransformLink transformer subclasses defined in the remarks for the documentation. For each GoXmlBindingTransformer you need to specify an element name, create a prototype object, and add bindings between attribute names and property names.

These two transformers produce an XML document such as:
<graph> <node Port="0" label="Linen" color="-331546" loc="112 195" /> <node Port="1" label="DarkKhaki" color="-4343957" loc="221 155" /> <node Port="2" label="LightSteelBlue" color="-5192482" loc="237 221" /> <node Port="3" label="DeepSkyBlue" color="-16728065" loc="146 288" /> <link from="0" to="1" label="zeroone" /> <link from="1" to="2" label="onetwo" /> <link from="2" to="3" label="twothree" /> <link from="0" to="3" label="zerothree" /> </graph>
Note that the ports get unique identifiers, not the nodes, because is true. If you also want the nodes to get unique identifiers, you can set to true. Neither identifier is at all related to an ..

As special cases, there are two property names that provide special behavior. For the , , , and classes, you can bind to the "Points" property in order to get or set the array of points used to define those shapes. The "Points" property is not treated specially for objects of any other type.

Also as a special case for node classes, the "TreeParentNode" property binding is handled as a reference to another node, where the other node is considered to be the "parent" node in a tree-structured diagram. This supports the definition of XML that only has elements for nodes, with an implicit link from a "parent" node to the node whose element includes the attribute corresponding to the "TreeParentNode" property. The property of this transformer provides a link that is copied when consuming such an element. The "TreeParentNode" property is not treated specially for objects that are not instances of IGoNode.

If you define a property binding using the special "TreeParentNode" property name, should not be true, because denotes nested XML elements, not the use of an attribute that refers to a node. It also does not make sense to have more than one attribute/property binding using the special "TreeParentNode" property name.

This single transformer for GoBasicNode produces an XML document such as:
<graph> <node id="0" label="Crimson" color="-2354116" loc="102 196" /> <node id="1" label="DarkCyan" color="-16741493" loc="210 157" parent="0" /> <node id="2" label="PaleGoldenrod" color="-1120086" loc="226 219" parent="0" /> <node id="3" label="Silver" color="-4144960" loc="343 254" parent="2" /> <node id="4" label="Purple" color="-8388480" loc="344 189" parent="2" /> </graph>
Note that the nodes have identifiers, not the ports. These identifiers are not at all related to an .. You can control which ports are used at each node in a tree diagram by setting the and properties of the transformer. You can also control whether links go from the parent node to the child node, or vice-versa, by setting the property.

and also make special provision for a root that is a whose Type is associated with a GoXmlBindingTransformer. When writing, the is used as the . When reading, if there is no , the is copied to be the . This makes it easy to bind properties with XML root attributes. However most of the other properties of transformers, such as or the other tree-related properties, are ignored when applied to the root object.

Bindings are inherited from transformers in the same manner that their corresponding Types inherit properties. So if you define a transformer for a Type C with a binding for the CProp property, and if you define a transformer for the Type D that inherits from C, the elements generated or consumed for instances of Type D will automatically include an attribute for the CProp property.

The binding mechanism uses reflection, so your application will need permission to use reflection. Using reflection is also slower than the equivalent functionality implemented as regular code that you implement in overrides of and .

member.name: T:Northwoods.Go.Xml.GoXmlTransformer
member.summary: This abstract class holds methods called by and , used to generate or parse XML for objects of a particular class.

remarks.para: When you define transformers for your application's object classes, you will want to inherit from this class. This provides standard implementations for all of the methods, which basically just call the same method on the base type's transformer.

To make it easier to access the 's and 's properties and methods, a number of their properties and methods are provided here also, whose implementations just delegate to the writer or reader. An instance of this class can only be used for one or at a time, not for both at once.

member.summary: Generate attributes for the current element, helping to render an object.
member.param: the object being generated

remarks.para: You will typically override this method to call methods such as or to read property values and set them on the object being initialized. The set of attributes usually matches those consumed in an override of .

This is called by .. If is true, this method also sees if . has an identifier associated with the given . If so, this writes out an "id" attribute with that identifier string. This method then calls on the , to allow another specific transformer to implement this behavior, or else calls ., to allow this 's base Type to provide a default behavior.

You should not try to define any "xmlns" namespaces. Instead, you can define the default namespace for the root element by setting ., and you can define namespaces and their prefixes by calling before XML generation.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.Xml.GoXmlTransformer.Allocate
member.summary: Override this method to construct a new object for the current XML element.
member.returns: An object of type , or null if no object needs to be created for the current element.
member.remarks: This is called by .. By default this returns a new instance of , if that property is not null and represents a class. This should be overridden to construct an object. The construction may need to use the values of some attributes on the current XML element in order to decide what to construct or which constructor to call. If this is called by a nested call to within an implementation of , then the property will refer to the object for which the body is being consumed. The can be used to find and return an existing child of the parent object, rather than constructing a new object as the child. Note that unlike the other implementations of methods, this method does not default to calling on the base Type, since that is unlikely to create an instance of the desired type.

remarks.para: Normally when you want to extend the behavior of a or a , you define your own transformer inheriting from and add it to the writer and/or the reader. You can do this for additional Types, or you can replace the transformer for a Type.

Sometimes you would like to modify the behavior of a transformer but for some reason you are unable to inherit from that -implementing class. This property makes it easier to insert additional functionality into an existing by replacing a particular Type's transformer with your own transformer that does some stuff and then delegates the rest of the implementation to the old transformer that had been registered for that Type.

remarks.para: There is a special use of GoXmlBindingTransformer when it applies to a that is the root. If the prototype object is a and if it is the value of ., this transformer's is used as the , and will call this transformer's method. If the prototype object is a and if an instance of it is the value of ., will call this transformer's method. This permits the use of this binding mechanism for binding root attributes with properties.
However, reading such a document will not make a copy of the prototype.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.Xml.GoXmlBindingTransformer.AddBinding(System.String,System.String,Northwoods.Go.Xml.GoXmlBindingFlags)
member.summary: Associate an attribute on this transformer's element with a property value on this transformer's type of object.
member.param: an XML attribute name
a .NET property name, or a sequence of properties separated by periods
flags describing the nature of the binding

remarks.para: See for examples.

This override also allow you to specify that this attribute, during consumption, defines the identifier by which a reference object may be referred to. The referred-to object is typically a child of a . For example, if you add a to your custom class, but do not want to have a separate XML element defining and describing that port, you will still need to generate the identifier for that port so that links will be able to find that port. If your node class defines a property that refers to your extra port, you can call this method to make sure the identifier is written for the port and that reading this attribute will make sure that node's port is given that identifier. transformer.AddBinding("xport", "SpecialPort", GoXmlBindingFlags.DefinesShared)

The order in which bindings are added determines the order in which properties are set when the attributes are consumed. Since setting some properties, such as the text string for a label, may modify the position or the location of a node, you should add the binding for a node's position or location last.
Setting the property is similar to defining a shared attribute property path for each of the ports on a node that has a name, as returned by .

As special cases, there are two property names that provide special behavior. For the , , , and classes, you can bind to the "Points" property in order to get or set the array of points used to define those shapes. The "Points" property is not treated specially for objects of any other type.

Also as a special case for node classes, the "TreeParentNode" property binding is handled as a reference to another node, where the other node is considered to be the "parent" node in a tree-structured diagram. This supports the definition of XML that only has elements for nodes, with an implicit link from a "parent" node to the node whose element includes the attribute corresponding to the "TreeParentNode" property. The property of this transformer provides a link that is copied when consuming such an element. The "TreeParentNode" property is not treated specially for objects that are not instances of IGoNode.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.Xml.GoXmlBindingTransformer.AddBinding(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Associate an attribute on this transformer's element with a property value on this transformer's type of object.
member.param: an XML attribute name
a .NET property name, or a sequence of properties separated by periods

remarks.para: transformer.AddBinding("label", "Text") will generate a "label" attribute whose value is the value of the "Text" property on the object being generated. When the element is consumed, the "Text" property of the newly copied object will be set to the value of the "label" attribute.

This mechanism can handle all of the data types for which there are predefined methods in to read and write attribute values. For example, if the data type of the property is Color, it will read the attribute using the method and will write the attribute using the method.

To support access to properties that are not defined on the transformer's Type, the can be a "path" of properties, separated by periods. For example: transformer.AddBinding("img", "Image.Name") where the is defined for a , will read and write the value of the GoIconicNode.Image.Name property.

As special cases, there are two property names that provide special behavior. For the , , , and classes, you can bind to the "Points" property in order to get or set the array of points used to define those shapes. The "Points" property is not treated specially for objects of any other type.

Also as a special case for node classes, the "TreeParentNode" property binding is handled as a reference to another node, where the other node is considered to be the "parent" node in a tree-structured diagram. This supports the definition of XML that only has elements for nodes, with an implicit link from a "parent" node to the node whose element includes the attribute corresponding to the "TreeParentNode" property. The property of this transformer provides a link that is copied when consuming such an element. The "TreeParentNode" property is not treated specially for objects that are not instances of IGoNode.

This mechanism has special code to handle Brushes and Pens, because those types must not be modified. Instead, they are cloned, the property is set, and then the brush or pen property is set on the shape object. However, in most cases, you should bind to the . and perhaps other GoShape.Brush... properties, and to the and properties, since those properties can handle the cases when there is no or value.

The child node and the link are then added to the ..

For each that is an immediate child object of the node, and that has a group child name, it calls to read an identifier for that port. member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.Xml.GoXmlBindingTransformer.HandlesNamedPorts
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the identifiers for named ports should be attributes on this element.
member.value: The default is false. This may be set to true for those transformers whose objects contain ports.

remarks.para: This is commonly set to true for node types that predefine a fixed set of ports, when it is not desired to represent information about each port besides the identifier. Thus it is natural to set this property to true for types such as GoBasicNode, GoIconicNode, GoTextNode, and GoSimpleNode.
See also the description for .
Note that this does not produce nested XML elements, unlike .
These port identifiers are not at all related to an ..

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.Xml.GoXmlBindingTransformer.HandlesChildren
member.summary: Gets or sets whether there are child objects of this that should be represented as nested XML elements in the body of this transformer's element.
member.value: This defaults to false.

remarks.para: If you are defining a transformer for a -inheriting class, you'll want to set this to true.
Setting this to true also automatically sets to true.

You may find that nested elements are being generated for child objects for which you do not want separate XML elements. This may happen, for example, when you define a transformer for the class and for a node class that has a predefined label as well as a variable number of additional children. You have at least two choices.

One choice is to replace all of those non-label child objects with instances of some class that inherits from . Because transformers are defined per type, this is an easy way to discriminate between the usages of text objects. Your transformer should then be defined for your custom class inheriting from , instead of for itself.

The other choice is to make the transformer for smarter. Use a transformer inheriting from and override the method to return true when the text object is actually a label handled as a node attribute, and to return false when the text object is supposed to be represented as a separate nested XML element.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.Xml.GoXmlBindingTransformer.ChildrenCollectionPath
member.summary: Gets or sets the property path to find the holding the child objects corresponding to nested elements when is true.
member.value: This defaults to the empty string, "", meaning that this transformer's object is the containing the child objects to be generated or consumed as nested XML elements.
member.remarks: For some complicated node classes, the group that is actually supposed to hold a varying collection of objects is not the node itself but a child or grandchild of the node. It is common for such a group to actually be a GoListGroup or something similar. This property just specifies a path from the transformer's object to that group.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.Xml.GoXmlBindingTransformer.HandlesChildAttributes
member.summary: Gets or sets whether this transformer gets to read or write attributes on elements in the body of this element.
member.value: This defaults to false.

remarks.para: This is usually set to true only when is also set to true. When this is true, and will be called for each child object of this transformer's (parent) object.

This property is infrequently used; but it is very handy when you want a "parent" object to associate attribute values with each "child" object, but those attributes are not properties on the "child" object. The only pre-defined use of this property is to help save bounds or path information for each node or link inside a collapsed subgraph.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.Xml.GoXmlBindingTransformer.HandlesSubGraphCollapsedChildren
member.summary: Gets or sets whether and handle collapsed s information about the saved relative bounds or saved paths of subgraph child s.
member.value: This defaults to false, and is only effective when and are both true.
member.remarks: You will probably want to set this to true for the transformer defined for your class.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.Xml.GoXmlBindingTransformer.TreeStructured
member.summary: Gets or sets whether nested XML elements are treated as logical child nodes connected by links, rather than being structural parts of nodes like subgraphs.
member.value: The default is false. This may be set to true for those transformers that represent nodes.

remarks.para:
When this property is true, the XML will typically look like:
<node id="0" label="Root" loc="71 190"> <node id="1" label="A1" loc="182 74" /> <node id="2" label="A2" loc="186 276"> <node id="3" label="B1" loc="272 236"> <node id="4" label="C1" loc="346 292"> <node id="5" label="D1" loc="445 259" /> <node id="6" label="D2" loc="448 348" /> </node> </node> <node id="7" label="B2" loc="287 358" /> </node> </node>

When this property is true, it does not make sense to have an attribute/property binding using the special property named "TreeParentNode". The "parent" of any node is implicit in the XML structure, so no node reference is necessary.
Setting this to true also automatically sets to true.

Caution: when generating XML, be sure that the collection that you assign to the . property only contains the root nodes of the trees. If the collection contains a child node as well as the root node, the XML element with nested elements will be generated in duplicate for that child node as well as for the whole tree starting at the root node.

member.name: T:Northwoods.Go.Xml.GoXmlSimpleData
member.summary: Use this abstract class to implement temporary data structures representing collections of properties that do not exist in your actual classes, in conjunction with s.

remarks.para: This abstract class does not define any properties, so there will not be any property name conflicts with any properties that you want to define.

example.para: The class holds a variable number of items, along with corresponding ports for each item. It would be natural to represent such a node in XML by having a fixed set of attributes corresponding to node properties, and then a collection of nested elements describing each of the items and their ports.

However, the class is not organized such that there is a collection of objects (s) that are holding an item and its ports. Instead an item has the same as the item's port. The items and ports all belong directly to the node in one big collection. So there is no class representing an "item" for which you could define a .
Instead you can define an auxiliary data class that holds the information about each item. Here's the start of such a definition:

Then one can define a transformer for MultiTextNodeItem and a transformer for that generates nested child elements for each item and then consumes them by creating the appropriate s and adding them to the .
However, you can avoid having to implement a transformer class for MultiTextNodeItem if you inherit from and define real .NET properties for each property you want to store so that you can use .

You can then define a for MultiTextNodeItem. The number of attributes/properties that you decide to read/write is dependent on your particular application's needs, of course. But one possibility is something like:
The for might be implemented as:
An example of the resulting XML could be:
example.code: <GoMultiTextNode id="30" ItemWidth="100" back="-18751" loc="36.5 379" TopPort="73" BottomPort="74"> <item text="first" sel="false" bold="true" width="100" wrap="100" LeftPort="75" RightPort="76" /> <item text="second" sel="true" bold="false" width="100" wrap="100" LeftPort="77" RightPort="78" /> <item text="third" sel="true" bold="true" width="100" wrap="100" LeftPort="79" RightPort="80" /> </GoMultiTextNode>

member.name: T:Northwoods.Go.Xml.GoXmlReader
member.summary: Read customizable XML, using class-specific s, using an XmlDocument or just an XmlReader.

remarks.para: Depending on which overload of Consume is called, you can either traverse an XmlDocument that you supply, you can load an XmlDocument from a Stream (if is true), or you can just handle the elements as they are read in by an XmlReader from a Stream (if is false). The processing of XML elements is basically done in a single pass, but there is built-in functionality for a second pass to fix up references in the objects that were constructed.
You must provide type-specific customizations by supplying instances of . Each transformer is associated with a Type () and an ElementName string ().

By default there are no transformers registered for this reader, so this reader is unable to actually do anything with the XML elements it sees. You will need to call for each class of object for which you want to consume XML. These calls to are sometimes done in an override of , but you probably do not need to define a class inheriting from .

does the bulk of the work to traverse the elements in the XmlDocument root, or (if is false) just to read elements from the . As this reader processes each element, it calls . calls to actually allocate an object, and if an object is allocated, calls , and to actually reconstruct the rest of the object.

Although most of the information that needs to be reconstructed will be held in attributes of the element representing an object, there will sometimes be references to other objects. If you can be sure that the references will be to objects that have already been read, you can call to remember an object by a key string, and you can call to recover that object by using the same key.

However, if the reference is to something that might not yet have been read and constructed, you can make use of the delayed-references mechanism that this reader offers. You can just call to remember the referring object, the property or other identifying string of the reference in this referring object, and the reference string to the referred-to object. This reference string is the same as the key used to identify shared objects.

Then the method, called as a "second pass" after all of the elements in the XML root have been read, iterates over all of those delayed references, calls to resolve the reference, and then calls so that the transformer gets a chance to fix up the reference.
The various Invoke... methods do the actual lookup for a transformer and invoke the respective method on the first transformer found.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.Xml.GoXmlReaderWriterBase.ObjectStack
member.summary: Gets an List of Object acting as a stack of Objects that have been created during the walking of the XML tree during Consume, or that have been seen during Generate.

remarks.para: During a .Consume, the bottom object, at index zero, will be the result of . will push the result of onto this stack just before calling , and then pop it off immediately afterwards. Hence during the processing of an element's body, i.e. during calls to ., the value of will be that parent element. Access to the whole stack of objects may be needed for establishing the context in which objects should be searched for, created, or modified. For example, when reading an element representing a node that has nested elements representing parts of the node, such as ports, the transformer for ports may need to implement to return an existing port of the node, rather than blindly allocating a new one that would conflict with the existing port.

During a .Generate, the bottom object, at index zero, will be the value of . will push the argument Object onto this stack just before calling , and the pop it off immediately afterwards. Hence during the processing of an element's body, i.e. during calls to ., the value of will be that "parent" object. Access to the whole stack of objects may be needed for establishing the context in which objects should generated, or to permit communication between the transformers for those objects.

member.name: T:Northwoods.Go.Xml.GoXmlWriter
member.summary: Write customizable XML, using class-specific s, creating an XmlDocument or just writing to an XmlWriter.

remarks.para: To produce XML, this class opens a , generates XML instructions, starts a root element, and then iterates twice over the set of . The first pass (implemented by ) gives each object a chance to detect and remember shared objects and set up other definitions in preliminary XML elements that are part of the root. The second pass (implemented by ) actually produces elements for the .

You must provide type-specific customizations by supplying instances of . Each transformer is associated with a Type. As this writer processes each object that it is rendering, it searches for the appropriate transformer to invoke, starting with that type and trying its base types.

By default there are no transformers registered for this writer, so this writer is unable to actually do anything with the specified . You will need to call for each class of object for which you want to produce XML. These calls to are sometimes done in an override of , but you probably do not need to define a class inheriting from .
For the pass, is called for each object in , which in turn calls on the registered transformer for the object's Type.

For the pass, is called for each object in , which in turn calls , , , and
on the registered transformer for the object's Type.
The various Invoke... methods do the actual lookup for a transformer and invoke the respective method on the first transformer found.

member.summary: Start a new XML element, with the name given by , and an optional and an optional associated namespace .
member.param: the local name for the element; must not be null

remarks.para: This starts a new element with the given , if not null. If a namespace is given, that is associated with the new element, and with the prefix, if it was given. You need to make a corresponding call to when you are finished writing this element. This method will write to the if it is available or else it will create an XML element as a child of the . If we are constructing a DOM instead of writing to a stream, this sets to be the newly started XmlElement.

Note that GoXml currently does not support multiple s with the same but different namespaces. You can call this method if you need to generate an element in a namespace other than the . Calling this method does not modify this writer's table of prefix to namespace mappings -- it does not call .

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.Xml.GoXmlWriter.SetNamespaceUri(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Define the namespace URI for a prefix string, used when writing prefixed attribute names.
member.param: must not be null
if null this method removes any URI associated with the
member.remarks: This should be called to establish a namespace URI for a prefix before calling or with a name that has that prefix. To specify the default namespace for the root element, set the property. Calls to this method before a call to a Generate method will result in the addition of "xmlns:prefix" attributes in the root element.

example.para:
The above code causes the root element to have an "xmlns" attribute. It also defines a prefix, "xlink", that refers to a particular namespace URI. The result may look like:
<svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> ... </svg>
The above transformer method example is simplified from the code used by the SVG transformer for GoImages, where there needs to be a link to the element representing the actual Image.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.Xml.GoXmlWriter.Objects
member.summary: Gets or sets the collection of objects to be generated.
member.value: This must be set before calling or .

remarks.para: Caution: implements ICollection, so if you set this property to refer to a node in your document, this writer will try to generate XML for the parts of your node, which is probably not what you intend.

Caution: If you are generating tree-structured XML corresponding to a logically tree-structured graph of nodes and links, by making use of the . property, you will need to make sure that the collection that you assign to this property contains only the logical root nodes of the logical trees in your document. That transformer will automatically generate nested XML for the nodes corresponding to the tree-children of each node given in this collection property, and recursively through the whole tree. That will cause the generation of duplicate XML elements for every single logical node in your trees.
